DataElement.preferredName: Isolated Chemotherapeutic Limb Perfusion Limb Infusion Procedure Incomplete Therapeutic Procedure Incomplete Reason
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text identification of the reason an isolated limb infusion (ILI) or isolated limb perfusion (ILP) was not completed as scheduled.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Isolated Chemotherapeutic Limb Perfusion Limb Infusion Procedure Incomplete
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: To possess every necessary or normal part or component or step; having come or been brought to a conclusion._A procedure used to deliver anticancer drugs directly to an arm or leg but not to the rest of the body. The flow of blood to and from the limb is temporarily stopped with a tourniquet (a tight band around the limb). Catheters (small, flexible tubes) attached to a pump are put into an artery and a vein in the limb so that blood can be circulated through the pump into the limb. Anticancer drugs are injected into the catheters. Wrapping the limb in a heated blanket or warming the drugs or blood may help the drugs work better._A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream._Not whole; lacking some necessary part or detail; unfinished.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Infusion Procedure Isolated Chemotherapeutic Limb Perfusion
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream.:A procedure used to deliver anticancer drugs directly to an arm or leg but not to the rest of the body. The flow of blood to and from the limb is temporarily stopped with a tourniquet (a tight band around the limb). Catheters (small, flexible tubes) attached to a pump are put into an artery and a vein in the limb so that blood can be circulated through the pump into the limb. Anticancer drugs are injected into the catheters. Wrapping the limb in a heated blanket or warming the drugs or blood may help the drugs work better.

Concepts.definition: Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.

A procedure used to deliver anticancer drugs directly to an arm or leg but not to the rest of the body. The flow of blood to and from the limb is temporarily stopped with a tourniquet (a tight band around the limb). Catheters (small, flexible tubes) attached to a pump are put into an artery and a vein in the limb so that blood can be circulated through the pump into the limb. Anticancer drugs are injected into the catheters. Wrapping the limb in a heated blanket or warming the drugs or blood may help the drugs work better.
